instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00850: What is 820-00850? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.ISL9239: What is ISL9239? This is a charging chip for Macbook motherboards from 2016-2018 responsible for charging the battery and creating the power rail PPBUS_G3H.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.CHGR_ACOK: What is CHGR_ACOK? This is identical to SMC_BC_ACOK. This will come out of the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging chip when CHGR_ACIN & CHGR_DCIN are present, and is necessary for the onewire circuit to begin working. On most Macbooks, CHGR_ACOK needs to be present in order for PP3V42_G3H to flow to the onewire circuit so that the circuitry that allows the charger to communicate with the SMC will turn on.  .
definitions.820-00239: What is 820-00239? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Has 5V cycling down to 0V on right side only
threads.message: This board had very minor liquid-damage. The side that didn't have any visible liquid-damage is cycling every 5 seconds from 5V on F3000 and F3001. The other side stays steady at 5V. PPBUS is at 12.3V. LDO voltage is coming up to 3.4V and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> is also coming up to 3.4V. I haven't been able to find any shorts. Not sure how these 4 ports are divided where one side is having an issue the other side isn't.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Has 5V cycling down to 0V on right side only
threads.message:
Which schematic do you use for repair?
Compare diode on power lines of all <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips.
Does the board start with 12.3V at <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>?
It should have 13V there?
Seems like bad communication between SMC and <CHIP>ISL9239</CHIP>.
Do you get correct <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>CHGR_ACOK</SIGNAL>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Has 5V cycling down to 0V on right side only
threads.message:
As different as this board is from the older ones, the <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> areas are laid-out almost identically so I think the <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> is pretty accurate there. Diode measurements are all the same at around .180. Slightly higher than the older boards.
I'm guessing PPBUS should be 13V and yes, this is an SMC-related issue. Board is not turning on with either side plugged in. I don't see <SIGNAL>CHGR_ACOK</SIGNAL> in the 00239 schematic and I still can't find <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL>. There's nothing that's standing out yet. The SMC area is very different. Those <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> pads are gone.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Has 5V cycling down to 0V on right side only
threads.message:
I was looking 00840 schematic first; didn't know which one used you.
<SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> is there too (<RESISTOR>R7090</RESISTOR>).
<SIGNAL>SMC_AUX_OK</SIGNAL> is same as <SIGNAL>CHGR_ACOK</SIGNAL>...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Has 5V cycling down to 0V on right side only
threads.message: I believe I found <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> and it's at 3.3V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Has 5V cycling down to 0V on right side only
threads.message: <RESISTOR>R7090</RESISTOR> is either gone or has been moved to a place that's not very obvious. I can't find it. I went off of what looks like <RESISTOR>R8592</RESISTOR>. <SIGNAL>SMC_AUX_OK</SIGNAL> is also nearly impossible for me to locate. That whole area around <RESISTOR>R5187</RESISTOR> is completely different.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Has 5V cycling down to 0V on right side only
threads.message: Unfortunatelly no schematic, nor boardview available for this board...
